<<<code>>>: You can create a new iterator that wraps the original iterator and returns the wrapped object. Here's an example:
```
class WrappedIterator<T> implements Iterator<T> {
    private final Iterator<Item> delegate;

    public WrappedIterator(Iterator<Item> delegate) {
        this.delegate = delegate;
    }

    @Override
    public boolean hasNext() {
        return delegate.hasNext();
    }

    @Override
    public T next() {
        return new FacadeItem(delegate.next());
    }
}
```
Then you can use this wrapped iterator in your code:
```
Iterator<FacadeItem> iterator = new WrappedIterator<>(originalIterator);
while(iterator.hasNext()){
    FacadeItem facadeItem = iterator.next();
    // do something with facadeItem
}
```
Explanation: The above code creates a new iterator `WrappedIterator` that wraps the original iterator `delegate` and returns the wrapped object. The `hasNext()` method checks if the wrapped iterator has any more elements to return, and the `next()` method returns the wrapped object.

You can use this wrapped iterator in your code by creating an instance of it and using the `hasNext()` and `next()` methods to iterate over the elements.
